docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Welcome to OpenTezos, the most complete and open-source documentation on Tezos.

docs.title: Main properties of the first "blockchain"
docs.description: In this chapter, we will dig deeper into the main properties of the Bitcoin protocol, its developers, its P2P network and a few basics of the economy it uses.

docs.title: Introduction to other consensuses
docs.description: In this chapter, we will briefly introduce a few other public consensuses.

docs.title: Proof-of-work
docs.description: Proof-of-work was the first fully functional blockchain consensus ever created. It is still in use by Bitcoin and many other blockchains. It requires its users to mine for getting a chance earning a reward for validating transactions. In this chapter, we are going to look into the technical side of things and how mining works.

docs.title: Smart Contracts
docs.description: In this chapter, we're going to explain how and why Bitcoin's programming features are limited. We'll define what are Smart Contracts and how they are already present on Bitcoin. And finally, what is Gas and why it was introduced on Ethereum.

docs.title: Become a baker or a delegator
docs.description: Becoming a baker or a delegate on Tezos is a great way to contribute to the ecosystem while earning some profits. Baking (also called staking) is the process of forming new blocks on Tezos. This process is part of the Proof-of-Stake consensus (more on that in the Tezos basics module). The more bakers, the more decentralized and statistically safe this process is.

frontMatter.title: Become a baker or a delegator

docs.title: Receive a grant
docs.description: The goal of the Tezos Foundation is to develop the Tezos ecosystem, which includes offering grant programs. In this chapter, weâ€™ll take a closer look at how it works.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Tezos is user-centric blockchain. As seen in the governance chapter, the evolution of Tezos is decided by its stakeholders. Anyone can contribute, from reporting a simple issue to coding and developing a whole new platform based on Tezos, there are many opportunities that will benefit you and the ecosystem. In this module we will see how to:

docs.title: Contribute to OpenTezos
docs.description: The great website you are currently browsing is called OpenTezos and will later be merged with the upcoming wiki.tezos.com. It is therefore important that all the content here is up to date and error-free. If you see an error, you can either submit an issue or go a step further by actually correcting the error yourself and submitting it for review. Here is how to proceed:

next.title: Contribute to the Tezos Core Protocol

docs.title: Report an issue
docs.description: The simplest way to contribute is to report issues that you may have encounter while using Tezos or its related platforms.

docs.title: Contribute to the Tezos Core Protocol
docs.description: The full source code of Tezos is available on gitlab.com/tezos. Tezos is written in OCaml, an industrial-strength programming language supporting functional, imperative and object-oriented styles [1]. OCaml is a functional programming language that offers speed, an unambiguous syntax and semantics, and formal proofs of correctness.

frontMatter.title: Contribute to the Tezos Core Protocol

docs.title: Decentralized Exchanges
docs.description: An exchange is a marketplace where coins and tokens are traded. The core function of an exchange is to ensure fair and orderly trading and the efficient dissemination of price information for any pair trading on that exchange. Exchanges give companies, traders, and crypto-enthusiasts a platform from which to publicly sell and buy crypto-currencies.

docs.description: Question 1

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: What is DeFi ?

docs.title: Lending and Flash Loans
docs.description: It is likely that at some point in your life you have had to borrow some money, e.g. for a student loan, a car loan or a mortgage. Lending and borrowing are essential services in any financial system. Traditionally, lenders such as banks provide you with a loan in exchange for a fee, in the form of interest rates. Repaying said loan is enforced by legal contracts with the bank.

docs.title: On-chain Oracles
docs.description: Definition

docs.title: Stablecoins
docs.description: A stablecoin is a cryptocurrency whose price is fixed to another asset. Most stablecoins are pegged (fixed) to fiat currencies (currencies issued by a central bank) like the US Dollar.

docs.title: Synthetics
docs.description: //TODO: Manque dâ€™illustration

docs.title: Token Standards
docs.description: In the Blockchain ecosystem, any asset that is digitally transferable between two people is called a token. Tokens can be native to a blockchain, e.g. BTC is the native token of Bitcoin. Tokens can also be created and hosted on an existing blockchain via a smart contract. Some tokens, called stablecoins, are following the price of fiat currencies (e.g. USD, EUR). Others, called NFT, can enclose collectibles or art. Finally, tokens can represent rights of ownership of real-world estates or companies (i.e. stock tokens). In this chapter, we will see the main token types and token standards on Tezos.

docs.title: How Indexers Work?
docs.description: This chapter aims to describe the functioning of a traditional indexer and its components.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: This module focuses on blockchain explorers and blockchain indexers for Tezos,

docs.title: Private indexer
docs.description: The tools presented in this module so far, are fully public, meaning that everyone can use them. However, they are meant for public networks, and who the user is, is dependent on the infrastructure and configuration of these services. Some organizations are more interested in deploying their own private Tezos network, either for private testing before going public, or for entirely private use. Refer to the Private blockchain module for more info. Therefore, it is possible to use an indexer on private networks.

previous.title: Checkout your smart contract on TzStats

docs.title: How to use the tzStats blockchain explorer?
docs.description: In the previous chapter, we saw that there are different block indexers for different uses in the block explorers for the Tezos Blockchain. In this chapter, we will focus on TzStats which is the most popular and complete Tezos explorer.

docs.title: Checkout your smart contract on TzStats
docs.description: As a developer, you will often want to check the state of your deployed smart contracts. Using a blockchain explorer is a fast and easy way to do so. In this section, we will deploy a smart contract and check it out on TzStats.

docs.title: Instructions Reference
docs.description: This chapter provides an explicit list of all the most commonly used instructions in Michelson. It is not intended for you to read it as is but to use it as a reference during your developments.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: To write smart contracts for Tezos, you can either choose a high-level language such as LIGO or SmartPy, or the official low-level language called Michelson.

docs.title: Language Basics
docs.description: The Michelson language is the reference language for Tezos smart contracts. It is a low-level stack-based language and is also a Turing-complete language. This means it has basic operations allowing to read/write/compare values in-memory, has infinite memory, and allows conditional operators (e.g. if, switch instructions)

docs.title: Smart Contracts
docs.description: Smart contracts in Michelson

docs.title: Take away
docs.description: - Smart contracts in Tezos are implemented in the Michelson language which is a stack-based strongly-typed language.

docs.title: Tutorial
docs.description: This section introduces the main concepts of the Michelson language. It begins with the basics of stack manipulation then focuses on primitive types and more complex data structures. Finally the chapter focuses on specific features related to smart contracts concepts.

docs.title: Governance on-chain
docs.description: Tezos is a self-amending blockchain network that incorporates an on-chain mechanism for proposing, selecting, testing, and activating protocol upgrades without having to hard fork. [1]

docs.title: History of amendements
docs.description: As presented in the Governance on-chain chapter, the Tezos blockchain is constantly evolving through new amendments. In this chapter, we will go over a history of past proposals both approved and refused, and look at why.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Tezos is a public, open-source blockchain protocol relying on a low power consumption and energy-efficient consensus.

docs.title: Liquid Proof-of-Stake
docs.description: In "Blockchain Basics" module, you understood the main objective of a consensus mechanism is maintaining a common history throughout the whole peer-to-peer network. There are countless consensus algorithms and they all have pros and cons. Notably, the Bitcoin's Proof-of-Work has two flaws:

docs.title: Operations
docs.description: This chapter introduces the notion of Operations on Tezos, more commonly known as Transactions on other blockchains.

docs.title: Smart contracts
docs.description: In this chapter, you'll learn the Tezos smart contracts basics. Their components and the workflow to record and use them on the Tezos blockchain.

docs.title: Welcome to OpenTezos
docs.description: Welcome Tezos Developers! Explore the technical and economic concepts behind the Tezos Network, experiment with our tutorials, or start building your own Tezos Dapp. Each module will teach you a full concept of Tezos, ending with a quizz that will get you an official completion certification if you succeed.
